[/quote]

because there are logical flaws with the ideals of fascism[/quote]
Yeah, I guess I found that part interesting, fascism isn’t really covered too terribly much in highschool classes (which was where my last history class was).

item.title: Fascism
item.dc:creator: @Teh_Dew1 Teh_Dew
item.description:
@Teh_Dew1 wrote:

[quote=“super_, post:8, topic:395753”]fascism technically works, but its devoid of all human compassion and frankly evil

I’m skeptical, theres a few things wrong with this I know from my general knowledge.

Mussolini didn’t make the trains run on time. It’s one of those common misconceptions.

He wasn’t a secularist, the fascists were heavily in league with the Catholic church at the time.

The Nazis never claimed to be Fascists, but they did continually claim to be socialists, whereas Fascism, after 1921, repudiated socialism by name. Although Fascism had some influence on the National Socialist German Workers’ Party, other influences were greater, notably Communism and German nationalism.

Ah, the classic mistakes of thinking that what people call themselves matters. The Chinese call their country The People’s Republic Of China, even though its neither a republic nor of the people.
North Korea calls itself the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea.

he kept ties with the catholic church as it was simply another means of distracting the public and deluding them with lies… we all know Marx’s famous words, “Die Religion… ist das Opium des Volkes.”[/quote]

Did you make a after school program for you’re views on Fascism?

Read full topic

[quote=“yakman, post:4, topic:395753”]I’m skeptical, theres a few things wrong with this I know from my general knowledge.

Mussolini didn’t make the trains run on time. It’s one of those common misconceptions.

He wasn’t a secularist, the fascists were heavily in league with the Catholic church at the time.

The Nazis never claimed to be Fascists, but they did continually claim to be socialists, whereas Fascism, after 1921, repudiated socialism by name. Although Fascism had some influence on the National Socialist German Workers’ Party, other influences were greater, notably Communism and German nationalism.

Ah, the classic mistakes of thinking that what people call themselves matters. The Chinese call their country The People’s Republic Of China, even though its neither a republic nor of the people.
North Korea calls itself the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea.[/quote]

he kept ties with the catholic church as it was simply another means of distracting the public and deluding them with lies… we all know Marx’s famous words, “Die Religion… ist das Opium des Volkes.”

Relevant: A grandson of exterminated people stands at Auschwitz and touches people.
